title: What are some pieces with the hardest piano accompaniment parts? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here are my votes. This playful and utterly enigmatic interpretation of what perhaps inspired the first augurs of music: birdsong. I suppose some would classify this piece as a concerto for piano, but I personally wouldn't, as every instrumental part is immensely difficult and complex. I can't even begin to imagine how Aimard memorized this. Also funny because of how seriously Boulez and Aimard take themselves. So French.    The colorful piano part in Stravinsky's Petrouchka, especially in the 2nd movement, which alternates between explosive energy and lucid reflection. This video skips to the most relevant section.    Clement suggested the Ravel trio - and indeed it is uniquely feared among pianists - it demands both spontaneity and clarity in the most virtuosic of passages. Not to mention a great sense of musicianship to be one with your fellow musicians.

As mentioned by Sitan Chen, Schubert's Erlkönig is one of them.Other chamber works I can think of that have relatively difficult piano parts are:Beethoven violin sonata no 3 in E flat majorBeethoven violin sonata no 9 in A major (Kreutzer)Franck violin / cello sonata in A majorFaure violin sonatas (but I think the first one in A major is harder)Chopin cello sonata in G minorStrauss violin sonata in E flat majorRavel Piano trio in A minorBasically almost all of Brahms' chamber music that includes pianoRachmaninoff cello sonata in G minorAndre Jolivet Chant de Linos for flute and pianoBartók violin sonatas (but I think the first is harder)Messiaen theme and variations for violin and piano So far I can only come up with these. Anyone wants to add on?
